 21  """A class to calculate a similarity based on the Levenshtein  
 22  distance. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenshtein_distance. 
 23   
 24  If available, the python-Levenshtein package will be used which will provide 
 25  better performance as it is implemented natively. See 
 26  http://trific.ath.cx/python/levenshtein/ 
 27  """ 
 28   
 29  import math 
 30  import sys 
 31   

 32 -def python_distance(a, b, stopvalue=-1): 

 33      """Calculates the distance for use in similarity calculation. Python 
 34      version.""" 
 35      l1 = len(a) 
 36      l2 = len(b) 
 37      if stopvalue == -1: 
 38          stopvalue = l2 
 39      current = range(l1+1) 
 40      for i in range(1, l2+1): 
 41          previous, current = current, [i]+[0]*l1 
 42          least = l2 
 43          for j in range(1, l1 + 1): 
 44              change = previous[j-1] 
 45              if a[j-1] != b[i-1]: 
 46                  change = change + 1 
 47              insert = previous[j] + 1 
 48              delete = current[j-1] + 1 
 49              current[j] = min(insert, delete, change) 
 50              if least > current[j]: 
 51                  least = current[j] 
 52          #The smallest value in the current array is the best (lowest) value 
 53          #that can be attained in the end if the strings are identical further 
 54          if least > stopvalue: 
 55              return least 
 56   
 57      return current[l1] 

 58   

 59 -def native_distance(a, b, stopvalue=0): 

 60      """Same as python_distance in functionality. This uses the fast C  
 61      version if we detected it earlier. 
 62   
 63      Note that this does not support arbitrary sequence types, but only  
 64      string types.""" 
 65      return Levenshtein.distance(a, b) 

 66   
 67  try: 
 68      import Levenshtein as Levenshtein 
 69      distance = native_distance 
 70  except Exception: 
 71      import logging 
 72      logging.warning("Python-Levenshtein not found. Continuing with built-in (slower) fuzzy matching.") 
 73      distance = python_distance 
 74   

 75 -class LevenshteinComparer: 

 76 -    def __init__(self, max_len=200): 

 77          self.MAX_LEN = max_len 

 78   

 79 -    def similarity(self, a, b, stoppercentage=40): 

 80          similarity = self.similarity_real(a, b, stoppercentage) 
 81          measurements = 1 
 82   
 83  #        chr_a = segment.characters(a) 
 84  #        chr_b = segment.characters(b) 
 85  #        if chr_a and chr_b and abs(len(chr_a) - len(a)) + abs(len(chr_b) - len(b)): 
 86  #            similarity += self.similarity_real(chr_a, chr_b, stoppercentage) 
 87  #            measurements += 1 
 88  #        else: 
 89  #            similarity *= 2 
 90  #            measurements += 1 
 91  # 
 92  #        wrd_a = segment.words(a) 
 93  #        wrd_b = segment.words(b) 
 94  #        if len(wrd_a) + len(wrd_b) > 2: 
 95  #            similarity += self.similarity_real(wrd_a, wrd_b, 0) 
 96  #            measurements += 1 
 97          return similarity / measurements 

 98   

 99 -    def similarity_real(self, a, b, stoppercentage=40): 

100          """Returns the similarity between a and b based on Levenshtein distance. It 
101             can stop prematurely as soon as it sees that a and b will be no simmilar than 
102             the percentage specified in stoppercentage. 
103   
104             The Levenshtein distance is calculated, but the following should be noted: 
105                 - Only the first MAX_LEN characters are considered. Long strings differing 
106                   at the end will therefore seem to match better than they should. See the 
107                   use of the variable penalty to lessen the effect of this. 
108                 - Strings with widely different lengths give the opportunity for shortcut. 
109                   This is by definition of the Levenshtein distance: the distance will be  
110                   at least as much as the difference in string length. 
111                 - Calculation is stopped as soon as a similarity of stoppercentage becomes 
112                   unattainable. See the use of the variable stopvalue. 
113                 - Implementation uses memory O(min(len(a), len(b)) 
114                 - Excecution time is O(len(a)*len(b)) 
115          """ 
116          l1, l2 = len(a), len(b) 
117          if l1 == 0 or l2 == 0: 
118              return 0 
119          #Let's make l1 the smallest 
120          if l1 > l2: 
121              l1, l2 = l2, l1 
122              a, b = b, a 
123   
124          #maxsimilarity is the maximum similarity that can be attained as constrained 
125          #by the difference in string length 
126          maxsimilarity = 100 - 100.0*abs(l1 - l2)/l2 
127          if maxsimilarity < stoppercentage: 
128              return maxsimilarity * 1.0 
129   
130          #Let's penalise the score in cases where we shorten strings 
131          penalty = 0 
132          if l2 > self.MAX_LEN: 
133              b = b[:self.MAX_LEN] 
134              l2 = self.MAX_LEN 
135              penalty += 7 
136              if l1 > self.MAX_LEN: 
137                  a = a[:self.MAX_LEN] 
138                  l1 = self.MAX_LEN 
139                  penalty += 7 
140   
141          #The actual value in the array that would represent a giveup situation: 
142          stopvalue = math.ceil((100.0 - stoppercentage)/100 * l2) 
143          dist = distance(a, b, stopvalue) 
144          if dist > stopvalue: 
145              return stoppercentage - 1.0 
146   
147          #If MAX_LEN came into play, we consider the calculated distance to be  
148          #representative of the distance between the whole, untrimmed strings 
149          if dist != 0: 
150              penalty = 0 
151          return 100 - (dist*1.0/l2)*100 - penalty 

152   
153   
154  if __name__ == "__main__": 
155      from sys import argv 
156      comparer = LevenshteinComparer() 
157      print "Similarity:\n%s" % comparer.similarity(argv[1], argv[2], 50)
